text: brazilian researchers have found that
snake venom could be used as a tool in
the fight against coronavirus after
early testing on animals has shown that
a molecule in the feminine of a deadly
south american pit viper could inhibit
the reproduction of covid cells sofia
trans-thompson has this report
the gerarakusu pit viper is one of the
deadliest snakes in south america
the viper's venom has enough potency to
kill 16 people but the dangerous snake
could potentially help scientists
develop a drug to combat coronavirus
researchers have found that the molecule
peptide produced by the gerarakusu pit
viper inhibited the viruses ability to
multiply in the cells of monkeys by 75
percent
we were able to see that the peptides
not only inhibited the development of
the virus in vitro inside the cell
but we were also able to see that it was
able to inhibit one of the proteins that
is very important for the development of
the virus and propagation of new viruses
and the peptides can be synthesized in a
lab making the capture or breeding of
the snakes unnecessary
we are afraid that people will go
hunting for the snakes all over brazil
thinking it will save the world
themselves or their family that's not
the case is this an important discovery
without a doubt it is
but chasing after the animal is not how
it will be resolved the component that
was discovered is just a fraction from
inside the venom it's not the venom
itself that will cure coronavirus
researchers will next test the
efficiency of different doses of the
molecule and whether it's able to
prevent the virus from entering cells
but it will be a slow testing process
and so far there's no timeline on when
human testing will begin
sophia tran thompson bbc news
